reviewText: "Life on Earth" is a classic from my childhood. I have the book, too. This was better than elementary school! I and my father frequently gasped at the daring (or seemingly daring) antics of David Attenborough, and my father loved to mimic his British English accent. I also remember a curious article in a Swedish newspaper, claiming that Attenborough was originally considered unsuitable as narrator "since he has too big teeth". Too big...what?! My father commented: "Well, he could point to them and claim it's a fossil". LOL.Otherwise, two things stand out when I look back. One is that I missed the last episode, the one dealing with man. The other is that I don't remember Attenborough's famous encounter with the mountain gorilla! Weird. That being said, "Life on Earth", with or without the dental work, deserves five stars and more.Note: This is a review of the series, not this particular DVD, which I haven't seen. Amazon has placed the DVD reviews on the product page of an abridged VHS version of the series, as well, creating some confusion in the community.At the moment, part of the series is available free of charge at Youtube, so you might consider watching it there before the BBC shows its teeth. Or fangs, as it were.
summary: Sink your teeth in this one

reviewText: This series was one of the best I have ever seen and I, like the reviewers before me, am hereby expressing my disgust and impatience that this wonderful series is not available for the USA and Canada.  WHY NOT?Does anyone who reads these reviews at Amazon ever answer our questions?????When and how can we get this series? Please tell us. I am tempted to get some of his newer series, but I doubt I'll love them as much as I did this one. As I've titled my review, it was irreplaceable.Cheers!
Title: N/A

reviewText: I have always been fascinated by David Attenborough's work.It amazes me how he can convey so much information is such a compact package - never repeating a word, yet making it digestible and memorable.  Most importantly, he has a traditional presentation style - yet without the aura of a college professor.  Only Sir David could have woven such a captivating "story" from the events and images of natural history.The photography was better than excellent for its day.  Of course, you cannot make a landmark documentary if the teleplay is anything but extraordinary.If I were to rate this product on its writing, photography and other aspects of production, I would have given it 6 stars.But I am disappointed that BBC has marketed this paragon of documentaries without sharpening up the picture and sound! What a shame! At least the contrast could have been easily increased -I remember seeing "Star Trek the Original Series" on DVD a few months ago - it appears to have been made yesterday... why couldn't the BBC adopt a few tips and tricks from CBS video?I am disappointed that this DVD in today's day and age looks like a washed out VHS tape.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I have been waiting for this to come out on DVD for a very long time. I finally got an all-region player so I will have not trouble with playing this once I get it.This was one of two very strong influences on my life as a kid. The other was the books of Gerald Durrell (which I highly recommend to anyone who is a fan of natural history or even just wants to laugh and cry at the same time). From David Attenborough I learned what was at the time the most complete basic story of life on planet Earth. There is some information which is definitely out of date, but that should not stop this from being available to a wide audience. Beyond the first two episodes, which tackled the thorny conundrum of the actual origins of life, most of the other disproved or changed material is actually fairly minor. Even though we have a much better idea about how life may have originally evolved from non-living organic chemistry, today we are still trying to determine the most likely paths. Attenborough's 1979 explanation is fine as long as this is kept in mind. Aside from this, the antiquated information consists mainly of details which matter little to a basic understanding of the evolutionary process. These changes were largely in relationships between various groups of organisms. Most notable is that officially at this time Dinosaurs were still considered to be cold-blooded reptiles rather than warm-blooded precursors to birds. Though the relationship to birds was strongly evident, the warm-bloodedness was about seven years away from being proven by Robert Bakker and the other "dinosaur heretics".The real reason to keep this series alive, however, is the phenomenal nature photography. This series not only filmed many intimate moments of animals and plants for the first time but contains some footage which can never be reshot. I specifically refer to the recently-discovered (at the time) Darwin's Frog which incubated its eggs in the male's vocal sack. This unique and beautiful little frog has since gone extinct along with hundreds of other frog species all over the planet. To my knowledge, the birth scenes shot for this series are the only existing visual record of Darwin's Frog actually giving birth.The only reason I have given this product 4 stars is that in other places I have seen references to only 10-episodes in this edition. If this turns out to be false, I will definitely change this rating to a full 5-stars.Bottom line: this is my favorite nature documentary ever produced, dated or not. What I would have loved is if David Attenborough could have updated and expanded it over the years.P.S: a bit of science trivia: at the time "Life On Earth" was written and filmed platetectonics had only been officially accepted as an explanation for the arrangement of the continents for about 6 years.

reviewText: While David Attenborough had already been presenting some programs on zoology in the black & white series `Zoo quest', it is `Life on Earth' that is really the first of his big nature television series works. 13 episodes long the template is based on Clarke's `Civilisation' TV series and would later be adopted by Carl Sagan for `Cosmos'.Life on Earth is about the evolution of life starting with a barren earth and working through the increase of the complexity of life. Each episode ends with the group of organisms evolving into a new type of environment and adapting to produce new traits. The last episode is about humans and human environments.This is one of the finest nature programs ever made. I cannot underestimate its value or recommend it enough. After you have finished watching this, move onto his next series `The Living Planet'.
summary: New to David Attenborough? Start here with his evolution of life
